guide.title: Gentoo Linux Frequently Asked Questions
guide.abstract: This FAQ is a collection of questions and answers collected from the gentoo-dev mailing list and from IRC -- if you have any questions (or answers!) to add, please contact an author.

section.title: How is Gentoo pronounced, and what does it mean?

body.p: Gentoo is a species of small fast penguin, pronounced "jen-two".

section.title: What makes Gentoo different?

body.p: Gentoo Linux is a fast, modern distribution with a clean and flexible design -- in this respect, Gentoo may appeal to Slackware, Linux From Scratch or BSD users. Unlike most Linux distros, Gentoo has a package system reminscient of BSD's ports, meaning the packages are continually updated to the lastest versions.

section.title: What is the differenence between the sys and build tarballs?

body.p: The build tarball is a minimal system capable of connecting to the internet and rebuilding itself, whereas sys is a complete comfortable system.
body.note: If you need a minimal system for recovery, you might want to try the bootable rescue disk images instead.

section.title: How do I install with no ISO image?

body.p: You use the boot floppies and the sys and build tarballs as normal. Please visit the Download/Install page for more information.

section.title: I'm finding things to be really unstable and I'm using "-O9 -ffast-math -fomit-frame-pointer" optimizations. What gives?

body.p: When you use any optimizations beyond -O3, you're really taking the risk of having broken packages. Very aggressive optimizations sometimes cause the compiler to streamline the assembly code to the point where it doesn't quite do the same thing anymore. Loc-Dog (on IRC) uses -O3 -mcpu=1686 -march=i686 -fforce-addr -fomit-frame-pointer -funroll-loops -frerun-cse-after-loop -frerun-loop-opt -malign-functions=4, which is about as much as I'd want to push global optimization settings. Beyond this, it's best to use ultra-high optimizations only with specific packages where you really need that extra 2%, and where you can easily test the package to ensure that it hasn't been optimized into oblivion.

section.title: What's the default root password after installation?

body.p: The default password is blank; hit enter.

section.title: How do I enable devfs?

body.p: devfs support is compiled-in to our standard kernels, and is enabled by default on Gentoo Linux 1.0_rc5 and above. If you're using 1.0_rc5 or greater, you don't need to do anything special to get devfs working; it's already active. However, if you are using a version of Gentoo Linux prior to version 1.0_rc5, add devfs=mount to your GRUB kernel boot options so that the line looks something like kernel /boot/boot/bzImage devfs=mount foo=bar The kernel will then mount the /dev devfs filesystem automatically at boot-time.

section.title: How do I get a /dev/mouse that doesn't go away when I reboot?

body.p: You need to edit /etc/devfsd.conf and add these lines:
body.pre: REGISTER ^misc/psaux$ CFUNCTION GLOBAL symlink misc/psaux mouse UNREGISTER ^misc/psaux$ CFUNCTION GLOBAL unlink mouse
body.p: If you are not using the devfs PS/2 mouse /dev/misc/psaux device, adjust the misc/psaux strings above accoringly. You'll then want to killall -HUP devfsd to get devfsd to reread /etc/devfsd.conf.

section.title: Grub can't find stage x.y?

body.p: During installation the grub boot files are copied to /boot/boot/grub. Grub automatically looks in the /boot/grub directory on the boot partition. (We strongly recommend having a separate no-auto boot partition mounted at /boot, since that way it is much more difficult to clobber your kernel and boot info by accident.) The above error generally arises from (a) not using a separate boot partition, (b) forgetting to mount the boot partition at /boot before either unpacking the build snapshot or running emerge --usepkg system, or (c) forgetting the notail option when mounting /boot. You can get more information on grub, including how to debug grub from the grub prompt, by reading the IBM developerWorks Grub tutorial.

section.title: I'm getting ALSA errors -- "mixer #/# not found", etc.

body.p: Your ALSA sound devices need to be set up correctly. To do this, grab our updated snddevices script and execute it by typing bash snddevices. This will configure the ALSA devices correctly, and these errors should go away and ALSA should now work.

section.title: In what format are the packages stored?

body.p: They exist in our portage tree as ebuilds; we are primarily a ports-based distribution, meaning that we provide scripts (.ebuild files) and a special system (Portage) so that you can build apps from sources. We generally only build binaries for releases and snapshots. The Development HOWTO covers the contents of an ebuild script in detail. For ISO releases, we create a full suite of binary packages in an enhanced .tbz2 format (.tar.bz2 compatible with meta-information attached to the end of the file.)

section.title: Why write a new port system (Portage) instead of using BSD's version?

body.p: One of the design philosophies of the .ebuild syntax was to make it an analog of what you'd type to install the program manually, thus making Portage very easy to learn and modify to your needs.

Gentoo Linux is designed from the ground up to be as fast as possible; Open, Net and FreeBSD use make for their ports system, which keeps it relatively slow; ebuild is specifcally designed to be small, fast, clean and extensible. Whereas BSD's ports is a relatively unchangable system and tricky to modify, Portage can be adapted to your specific needs. Portage is meant to be a working tool, not just a hard-to-understand system that comes as-is. Portage is designed to allow you to interact with it at all levels.

section.title: How does this differ from Debian's apt or BSD's ports?

body.p: Portage features the best of apt and ports; for example, USE options, a full dependency system, safe installs and uninstalls, and a true package database. Think of Portage as the best of both worlds; a ports system with the sensibilities and safety of a package management system built-in.

section.title: How do I install and uninstall packages?

body.p: The Portage User Guide details how to install and uninstall packages, and update Portage.

section.title: What happened to /etc/make.defaults?

body.p:
As of Portage 1.5 onwards, /etc/make.defaults is antiquated; if you have portage-1.5-r1 or above installed then you can safely delete it. This file has been replaced by /etc/make.profile/make.defaults (/etc/make.profile should actually be a symlink to /usr/portage/profiles/default), which contains system profile-specific default settings. The priority order of the various configuration files is as follows (highest first):
Environment variables
/etc/make.conf, for your use
/etc/make.profile/make.defaults, for profile-specific defaults
/etc/make.globals, for global defaults (settings not specified in any other place come from here)

section.title: Is there a way to upgrade all installed packages a la apt-get upgrade or make World?

body.p: Not yet, although such functionality is being worked upon. For the moment you can use emerge --pretend update to list upgradable packages, but the actual upgrading has to be done package by package (using ebuild or emerge). Otherwise, things may get merged in a slightly non-optimal order.

section.title: What if rsync doesn't work for me?

body.p: If you're behind a firewall that doesn't permit rsync traffic, then you can instead download the daily /usr/portage snapshot from http://cvs.gentoo.org/snapshots. Just unpack the tarball (using tar xvjf portage-foo.tbz2) in the /usr directory.

section.title: Can I rsync from another operating system?

body.p: There's a program called unison that works under both UNIX and Win32, available from http://www.cis.upenn.edu/~bcpierce/unison/.

section.title: ReiserFS and filesystem corruption issues -- how to fix'em, etc

body.p: Since kernel 2.4.4, ReiserFS has been very stable and ready for production environments. However, if you have been using ReiserFS since before kernel 2.4.4, then it's recommended that you back up all your important data and recreate your ReiserFS filesystems with a 2.4.4+ kernel and a recent version of reiserfsutils. If this isn't possible, try using a recent Gentoo Linux boot/rootdisk to boot your system, and then run reiserfsck --rebuild-tree on the corrupted filesystem. This should make the filesystem consistent again, although you may have lost some files or directories due to corruption.

section.title: Where can I report bugs?

body.p: For bugs within a specific program, contact the program's author. Otherwise, contact the gentoo-dev mailing list, or on #gentoo on the openprojects irc network.

section.title: How oftern are new releases made?

body.p: New releases are announced on the gentoo-announce mailing list.

section.title: I would like a package to be added to Portage; how would I go about this?

body.p: Send an email containing your ebuild to the gentoo-ebuild mailing list, and it will be committed to cvs.

section.title: How can I add a question or answer to this FAQ?

body.p: You can email an author directly, email the Developer Discussion mailing list, or drop by on #gentoo on the openprojects irc network.

section.title: Where can I find more about supervise?
Where can I find more information about Gentoo Linux?

body.p: The official Gentoo documentation can be found on http://www.gentoo.org; general Linux information is at http://www.linuxdoc.org.

section.title: Can I buy a CD of Gentoo Linux?

body.p: Not currently, although we will most likely be selling CDs in the future. Stay tuned!
